◎ Positive Finding on Most Recent Stool Test
◎ Abnormal Finding on Most Recent Colorectal Imaging
◎ Abnormal Finding on Most Recent Flexible Sigmoidoscopy
◎ Abnormal Finding on Most Recent Colonoscopy
◎ Family History of Colon Cancer, Colon Cancer Syndrome or Advanced Adenoma

◎ Iron Deficiency Anemia. Iron deficiency anemia may be a symptom of colon cancer. It must be considered in combination with other clinical factors, such as unintentional weight loss, changes in bowel habits, visible blood in the stool, and recent hemoglobin lab test results.

TSR-NoCode

[a997cc03-3e99-40eb-833a-6374c7750a3a |Observation procedure (procedure)]- ->(363702006 |Has focus (attribute))->[107674006 |Cytologic finding (finding)]- ->(116676008 |Associated morphology (attribute))->[55237006 |Severe dysplasia (morphologic abnormality)];

A group of related alternative actions is a sentence group if the item referenced by the action is the same in all the actions, and each action simply constitutes a different variation on how to specify the details for that item. For example, two actions that could be in a SentenceGroup are "aspirin, 500 mg, 2 times per day" and "aspirin, 300 mg, 3 times per day". In both cases, aspirin is the item referenced by the action, and the two actions represent two different options for how aspirin might be ordered for the patient. Note that a SentenceGroup would almost always have an associated selection behavior of "AtMostOne", unless it's a required action, in which case, it would be "ExactlyOne".
A group with this behavior logically groups its sub-elements, and may be shown as a visual group to the end user, but it is not required to do so.
Any group marked with this behavior should be displayed as a visual group to the end user.
Any number of the items in the group may be chosen, from zero to all.
All the items in the group must be selected as a single unit.
All the items in the group are meant to be chosen as a single unit: either all must be selected by the end user, or none may be selected.
The end user must choose one and only one of the selectable items in the group. The user may not choose none of the items in the group.
The end user may choose zero or at most one of the items in the group.
The end user must choose a minimum of one, and as many additional as desired.
An action with this behavior must be included in the actions processed by the end user; the end user may not choose not to include this action.
An action with this behavior may be included in the set of actions processed by the end user.
An action with this behavior must be included in the set of actions processed by the end user, unless the end user provides documentation as to why the action was not included.

An action with this behavior is one of the most frequent actions that is, or should be, included by an end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the action to the end user should consider "pre-checking" such an action as a convenience for the user.

An action with this behavior is one of the less frequent actions included by the end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the actions to the end user would typically not "pre-check" such an action.
An action with this behavior may only be completed once.
An action with this behavior may be repeated multiple times.
This item, in a list entry, allows the user to enter a fill in value that is not present in the set of presented choices.
For a particular action or action group, specifies whether the elements are read only.

bibliodiv.title: Supporting Evidence
bibliodiv.bibliomixed: Giardiello 2014 Giardiello FM, Allen JI, Axilbund JE, et al. Guidelines on genetic evaluation and management of Lynch syndrome: a consensus statement by the US Multi-Society Task Force on colorectal cancer. Am J Gastroenterol. 2014 Aug;109(8):1159-79. (link)

Johnson 2014 Johnson DA, Barkun AN, Cohen LB, et al; US Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer. Optimizing adequacy of bowel cleansing for colonoscopy: recommendations from the US multi-society task force on colorectal cancer. Gastroenterology. 2014;147(4):903-924. (link)

Levin 2008 Levin B, Lieberman DA, McFarland B, et al; American Cancer Society Colorectal Cancer Advisory Group; US Multi-Society Task Force; American College of Radiology Colon Cancer Committee. Screening and surveillance for the early detection of colorectal cancer and adenomatous polyps, 2008: a joint guideline from the American Cancer Society, the US Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer, and the American College of Radiology. CA Cancer J Clin. 2008;58(3):130-160. (link)

Lieberman 2012 Lieberman DA, Rex DK, Winawer SJ, Giardiello FM, Johnson DA, Levin TR. Guidelines for colonoscopy surveillance after screening and polypectomy: a consensus update by the US Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer. Gastroenterology. 2012;143(3):844-857. (link)

NCHPCP 2017a National Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention. Get Recommended Screening Tests and Immunizations for Men. Accessed August 25, 2017. (link)

Accessed August 25, 2017. (link)

Rex 2017 Rex DK, Boland CR, Dominitz JA, et al. Colorectal cancer screening: recommendations for physicians and patients from the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer. Gastroenterology. 2017;153(1):307-323. (link)
Shaukat 2013 Shaukat A, Mongin SJ, Geisser MS, et al. Long-term mortality after screening for colorectal cancer. N Engl J Med. 2013;369(12):1106-1114. (link)

USPSTF 2016 U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Final Recommendation Statement: Colorectal Cancer: Screening.
